title: Igby Goes Down
descriptions:
Igby Goes Down (2002) follows Jason “Igby” Slocumb Jr., a sardonic, disaffected teenager from a wealthy but deeply dysfunctional New York family. His father, a brilliant man undone by schizophrenia, is institutionalized; his mother, Mimi, is a caustic, pill-popping socialite obsessed with control and appearances; his older brother, Oliver, is a polished, ambition-driven Republican-in-training. Feeling alienated and suffocated, Igby rebels against the expectations of privilege.

After flunking out of a string of prep schools, Igby is packed off to military academy, then escapes to Manhattan. He drifts through the bohemian underbelly of the city, squatting in the loft of his godfather, the cynical real estate mogul D.H., and getting entangled with D.H.’s volatile dancer-mistress, Rachel. Igby strikes up a fragile romance with Sookie, a witty, free-spirited Bennington student who represents a chance at authentic connection beyond his family’s toxicity.

Igby’s attempts at independence are messy and self-sabotaging. He hustles odd jobs, experiments with drugs, and ricochets between acerbic humor and wounded vulnerability. As he bounces between D.H.’s loft, Rachel’s chaos, and Sookie’s dorm, he confronts the inescapable gravity of his upbringing. Family secrets surface—especially about D.H.’s relationship to the Slocumbs—and the power dynamics around him shift. Igby’s bond with Sookie sours when her affections drift toward Oliver, reinforcing Igby’s belief that privilege and betrayal walk hand in hand.

Mimi’s failing health forces Igby back into the family orbit, where he’s pressured to perform the role of dutiful son. Instead, he lashes out, pushing for the truth and asserting control over his own fate. In the end, faced with the legacies of mental illness, emotional neglect, and moral compromise, Igby chooses exile over complicity. He cashes a final lifeline and heads west, intent on remaking himself far from the brittle pretenses of the Upper East Side.

Darkly comic and sharply observed, the film charts a coming-of-age defined by rebellion and self-preservation. Igby’s journey is less about redemption than about escaping a lineage that seems designed to break him, even as he struggles to avoid becoming another casualty of the world he loathes.
